description:
Haiti: The new COVID-19 strategy developed by MSPP and UN partners has been adopted by the Multisectoral Commission. It aims at fighting disbelief, denial and refusal behaviours as positive cases
increase. The strategy will use more deeply rooted socio-cultural messages, embodied by credible influencers,
community and religious leaders, as well as coordinate institutional and community-led messaging and reinforce
digital media, radio and TV.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 21, a Haitian presidential decree strictly prohibited sharing on social media any images of bodies of people who died from Covid-19 -- under the threat of fine of nearly $200 or 15 days in jail.

description: Beginning on May 21, 2020, Haiti prohibits taking and sharing photos or video of Covid-19 patients without their authorization. Violators can be fined 20.000 Gourdes, imprisoned for 15 days, and sentenced to 30 days of communal labor.

description:
Beginning midnight local time on March 16, Haiti is suspending flights from Europe, Canada, the Dominican Republic and Latin America for the next two weeks, Prime Minister Joseph Jouthe announced on Twitter.
Flights from the United States will still be permitted, "after an agreement with American authorities," Jouthe tweeted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: Beginning on February 9, 2021 Haiti will require a negative PCR or Antigen test taken less than 72 hours before boarding for all international air passengers into the country, as announced on February 3. Exempt from this rule are people who have recovered from COVID-19, they will have to present a positive test and a certificate of recovery from their physician.

description:
Haiti (Presidential Decree May 21, 2020):
Anyone who has been in close contact with a patient, suffering from the pandemic / epidemic virus, must automatically quarantine himself or go for screening within a period not exceeding forty-eight (48) hours or less, as specified by the Ministry of Public Health, and comply with all other measures to combat the pandemic / epidemic provided for by Order adopted by the Council of Ministers.

Original Text:
Toute personne ayant été en contact étroit avec un malade, atteint du virus de la pandémie / épidémie, doit se mettre automatiquement en quarantaine ou aller se faire dépister dans un délai ne dépassant pas quarante-huit (48) heures ou tout laps de temps plus court prévu par le Ministère chargé de la Santé Publique, et respecter toutes autres mesures de lutte contre la pandémie / épidémie prévues par Arrête pris en Conseil des Ministres
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
(Haiti) - Presidential decree: Any driver of a vehicle or transport equipment shall carry out disinfectant cleaning of the vehicle or transport equipment at least once a day.

The vehicle or transport equipment must be ventilated permanently.

The violation of these provisions by the driver is liable to three thousand (3,000.00) Gourdes of fine, five (5) days imprisonment or fifteen (15) days of community service to be determined by the Municipal Council.

Article 3.- Tout conducteur de véhicule ou matériel de transport procède au nettoyage désinfectant du véhicule ou matériel de transport au moins une fois par jour.

Le véhicule ou matériel de transport est en permanence aéré.

La violation de ces dispositions par le conducteur est passible de trois mille (3,000.00) Gourdes d'amende, de cinq (5) jours d'emprisonnement ou de quinze (15) jours de travail d'intérêt général à déterminer par le Conseil Municipal.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Haitian Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training (MENFP), as of April 6, 2020, has set up a Task Force to respond to COVID- 19 in the education sector. This Task Force has been working closely with the UN in coordinating the response. A response plan for the Education sector has been prepared aiming, among other objectives, to enable distance learning for students and their return to school when feasible.

description: Haiti: On 16 March, a Center of Permanent Information on the Coronavirus (CIPC) was launched by the Prime Minister and the Minister of Health. The CIPC is responsible for carrying out awareness-raising actions, health recommendations, through the media, or the coordination of the Ministry of Culture and Communication and under the direction of the Prime Minister's Office. The population will be informed about the prevention, protection and evolution of COVID-19 in the event of a possible appearance and spread of the virus on national soil. Two telephone lines (4343-3333 and 116), have been made available to the public for all information related to the Coronavirus.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: The Haitian Ministry of Health, in cooperation with the UN Population Fund (UNFPA), has launched the information program "ALo SajFanm" to inform pregnant women on protection measures for themselves and their babies with regard to the pandemic. Communication via 35 radio stations and printed documents.

description:
Haiti: Schools, universities, places of worship and industrial parks have been closed from March 19, 2020. 
Haiti will reopen its key textile industry next week, Prime Minister Joseph Jouthe said on Wednesday (Apr 15), the industry would start running at 30 per cent of its capacity to ensure social distancing in the workplace. UPDATE: From March 19, all industrial facilities had been closed. On April 15, it was announced that the textile industry would be allowed to reopen beginning on April 20 at 30% capacity to ensure social distancing.

description: On May 21 as infections rose, Haitian president Moïse announced sweeping new measures to prevent the spread of the virus. These prohibited any public gathering of more than five people, adding that those in violation would be fined 3,000 Haitian Gourdes (about $27) or possibly face a five-day prison sentence or a 15 days of community service.

description: In a press statement published on 30 April, the Prime Minister of Haiti announced the mandatory wearing of face masks in all public spaces as of 11 May. This measure particularly applies to employees in their workplace, drivers, passengers of public transportation, people circulating in any public space, as well as in hospitals, shops, banks and any other private or public institutions.
